sen.j: 賀茂 真淵（かも の まぶち、元禄10年3月4日 (旧暦)（1697年4月24日） - 明和6年10月30日 (旧暦)（1769年11月27日）は、江戸時代の国学者、歌人。
sen.e: KAMO no Mabuchi (April 24, 1697 - November 27, 1769) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and culture, and also a poet in the Edo period.
KAMO no Mabuchi (April 24, 1697-November 27, 1769) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and culture, and also a poet in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: ハイフン前後のスペース削除しました。
sen.e: KAMO no Mabuchi (April 24, 1697-November 27, 1769) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and culture, and also a poet in the Edo period.
He was commonly called Shosuke.
He was commonly called Shosuke.
He was commonly called Shosuke.

sen.j: 真淵は出生地の敷知郡にちなんだ雅号で、淵満とも称した。
sen.e: Mabuchi was his pseudonym, named after his birth place Fuchi County, and he also called himself 淵満.
sen.cmt: 「淵満」→読み方不明。原文のまま入力しました。
sen.e: Mabuchi was his pseudonym, named after his birth place Fuchi County, and he also called himself 淵満.
Mabuchi was his pseudonym, named after his birth place Fuchi County, and he also called himself 淵満.

sen.j: 賀茂真淵は1697年、浜松の神官である岡部政信の三男として生まれた。
sen.e: KAMO no Mabuchi was born in 1697 as the third son of Masanobu OKABE who was a Shinto priest in Hamamatsu.
KAMO no Mabuchi was born in 1697 as the third son of Masanobu OKABE who was a Shinto priest in Hamamatsu.
KAMO no Mabuchi was born in 1697 as the third son of Masanobu OKABE who was a Shinto priest in Hamamatsu.

sen.j: 岡部家は京都の賀茂神社の末流とされる。
sen.e: The Okabe family was said to be the descendant of the Kamo-jinja shrine.
The Okabe family is said to have been the descendant of the Kamo-jinja shrine in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 時制変更、「京都」が抜けていたので補完しました。
sen.e: The Okabe family is said to have been the descendant of the Kamo-jinja shrine in Kyoto.

sen.j: 37歳の時、京都に移り荷田春満を師として学んだが、1736年の師の他界に伴い、1738年、江戸に移住。
sen.e: At the age of 37, he moved to Kyoto and studied under KADA no Azumamaro, but in 1736 his teacher died and he moved to Edo in 1738.
At the age of 37, he moved to Kyoto and studied under KADA no Azumamaro, but in 1736 his teacher died and he moved to Edo in 1738.
At the age of 37, he moved to Kyoto and studied under KADA no Azumamaro, but in 1736 his teacher died and he moved to Edo in 1738.
He taught Japanese classical literature and culture.
He taught Japanese classical literature and culture.
He taught Japanese classical literature and culture.

sen.j: 1763年、本居宣長が伊勢参宮の旅の途中の賀茂真淵を訪れ、入門。
sen.e: In 1763, Norinaga MOTOORI visited KAMO no Mabuchi who was on the trip to Ise-jingu Shrine, and became his disciple.
In 1763, Norinaga MOTOORI visited KAMO no Mabuchi who was on the trip to Ise-jingu Shrine, and became his disciple.
In 1763, Norinaga MOTOORI visited KAMO no Mabuchi who was on the trip to Ise-jingu Shrine, and became his disciple.

sen.j: その夜、生涯一度限りの教えを受けた話は「松阪の一夜」として有名。
sen.e: On that night, he received such a valuable lecture only once in his life; this story is famous as "a night in Matsuzaka."
On that night, he received such a valuable lecture only once in his life; this story is famous as "a night in Matsuzaka."
On that night, he received such a valuable lecture only once in his life; this story is famous as "a night in Matsuzaka."

sen.j: 以後文通（万葉集問目）が続いたとされる。
sen.e: After that, they continued correspondence (questions and answers on Manyoshu [Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves]).
sen.cmt: 「万葉集問目」→定訳不明。"questions and answers on Manyoshu"と訳しました。（http://www.norinagakinenkan.com/collect/manyou_mon16.html参考）
sen.e: After that, they are said to have continued correspondence (questions and answers on Manyoshu [Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves]).
After that, they are said to have continued correspondence (questions and answers on Manyoshu [Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves]).

sen.j: 江戸の住居跡は、賀茂真淵県居の跡として東京都中央区 (東京都)（日本橋久松町9先）に説明書きが立っている。
sen.e: The former site of his residence in Edo is in Chuo Ward, Tokyo (near 9 Hisamatsu-cho, Nihonbashi) and a guide board stands there indicating the former site of KAMO no Mabuchi Agatai (his another pseudonym).
sen.cmt: 「県居」→賀茂真淵の号。説明を入れました。
sen.e: The former site of his residence in Edo is in Chuo Ward, Tokyo (near 9 Hisamatsu-cho, Nihonbashi, Tokyo) and a guide board stands there indicating the place is the former site of KAMO no Mabuchi Agatai (his another pseudonym).
sen.cmt: 「東京」を補完、「the place is」を挿入しました。
sen.e: The former site of his residence in Edo is in Chuo Ward, Tokyo (near 9 Hisamatsu-cho, Nihonbashi, Tokyo) and a guide board stands there indicating the place is the former site of KAMO no Mabuchi Agatai (his another pseudonym).

sen.j: また、墓は品川の東海寺大山墓地（東京都品川区北品川三丁目）にある。
sen.e: His tomb is at Oyama Cemetery of Tokai-ji Temple (3 Kitashinagawa, Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo).
His grave is at Oyama Cemetery of Tokai-ji Temple in Shinagawa (3 Kitashinagawa, Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo).
sen.cmt: 品川を補完、tombを変更しました。
sen.e: His grave is at Oyama Cemetery of Tokai-ji Temple in Shinagawa (3 Kitashinagawa, Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo).

sen.j: 浜松の生家の側には「賀茂真淵記念館」（静岡県浜松市中区 (浜松市)伊場一丁目22-2）がある。
sen.e: "Kamono Mabuchi Memorial Hall" is next to his birthplace in Hamamatsu (1-22-2 Iba, Naka Ward, Hamamatsu City, Shizuoka Prefecture).
"Kamono Mabuchi Memorial Hall" is near his birthplace in Hamamatsu (1-22-2 Iba, Naka Ward, Hamamatsu City, Shizuoka Prefecture).
sen.cmt: next toを原文に沿ってnearに変更しました。
sen.e: "Kamono Mabuchi Memorial Hall" is near his birthplace in Hamamatsu (1-22-2 Iba, Naka Ward, Hamamatsu City, Shizuoka Prefecture).

sen.j: 賀茂真淵は荷田春満（かだのあずままろ）を師とし、万葉集などの古典研究を通じて古代日本人の精神を研究した。
sen.e: KAMO no Mabuchi studied under KADA no Azumamaro and investigated the spirit of ancient Japanese through the study of classical literature such as Manyoshu.
KAMO no Mabuchi studied under KADA no Azumamaro and investigated the spirit of ancient Japanese through the study of classical literature such as Manyoshu.
KAMO no Mabuchi studied under KADA no Azumamaro and investigated the spirit of ancient Japanese through the study of classical literature such as Manyoshu.

sen.j: 荷田春満・本居宣長・平田篤胤とともに「国学の四大人（しうし）」の一人とされる。
sen.e: He is one of "the four great scholars of Japanese classical literature and culture" together with KADA no Azumamaro, Norinaga MOTOORI and Atsutane HIRATA.
He was one of 'the four great scholars of Japanese classical literature and culture' together with KADA no Azumamaro, Norinaga MOTOORI and Atsutane HIRATA.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションマーク変更、過去化しました。
sen.e: He was one of 'the four great scholars of Japanese classical literature and culture' together with KADA no Azumamaro, Norinaga MOTOORI and Atsutane HIRATA.

sen.j: 主な著書に『歌意考』『万葉考』『国意考』『祝詞考』『にひまなび』『文意考』『五意考』『冠辞考』『神楽考』『源氏物語新釈』などがある。
sen.e: His major works include "Kaiko" (Thoughts on the Meaning of Poetry), "Manyoko" (The Study of Manyoshu), "Kokuiko" (Thoughts on the Meaning of the Nation), "Noritoko" (Thoughts on Rituals), "Niimanabi" (New Studies), "Buniko" (Commentary on Literature), "Goiko" (Five Ancient Matters [Literature, Poetry, Nativism, Language and Writing]), "Kanjiko" (The Study of Poetic Epithets), "Kagurako" (Thoughts on Shinto Songs) and "Genji Monogatari Shinshaku" (New Interpretations of The Tale of Genji).
sen.cmt: 「神楽考」→「神楽歌考」という記載もあります。定訳不明。"Thoughts on Shinto Songs"と説明を入れました。
sen.e: His major works include "Kaiko" (Thoughts on the Meaning of Poetry), "Manyoko" (The Study of Manyoshu), "Kokuiko" (Thoughts on the Meaning of the Nation), "Noritoko" (Thoughts on Rituals), "Niimanabi" (New Studies), "Buniko" (Commentary on Literature), "Goiko" (Five Ancient Matters [Literature, Poetry, Nativism, Language and Writing]), "Kanjiko" (The Study of Poetic Epithets), "Kagurako" (Thoughts on Shinto Songs) and "Genji Monogatari Shinshaku" (New Interpretations of The Tale of Genji).

His major works include "Kaiko" (Thoughts on the Meaning of Poetry), "Manyoko" (The Study of Manyoshu), "Kokuiko" (Thoughts on the Meaning of the Nation), "Noritoko" (Thoughts on Rituals), "Niimanabi" (New Studies), "Buniko" (Commentary on Literature), "Goiko" (Five Ancient Matters [Literature, Poetry, Nativism, Language and Writing]), "Kanjiko" (The Study of Poetic Epithets), "Kagurako" (Thoughts on Shinto Songs) and "Genji Monogatari Shinshaku" (New Interpretations of The Tale of Genji).

sen.j: 國學院の編になる『賀茂真淵全集』（6巻）、またその増訂版である『増訂賀茂真淵全集』（12巻、吉川弘文館）および、『校本賀茂真淵全集』（思想編上下）、久松潜一監修『賀茂真淵全集』（28巻、続群書類従完成会）が刊行されている。
sen.e: They have been published in "Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (six volumes) compiled by Kokugakuin, its revised edition "Zotei Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Revised Edition of the Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (twelve volumes, published by Yoshikawa Kobunkan), "Kohon Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Conflated Edition of the Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (on his thoughts, two volumes) and "Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (twenty-eight volumes, published by Zokugun Shorui Ju Kanseikai) edited by Senichi HISAMATSU.

They have been published in "Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (six volumes) compiled by Kokugakuin, its revised edition "Zotei Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Revised Edition of the Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (twelve volumes, published by Yoshikawa Kobunkan), "Kohon Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Conflated Edition of the Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (on his thoughts, two volumes) and "Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (twenty-eight volumes, published by Zokugun Shorui Ju Kanseikai) edited by Senichi HISAMATSU.

They have been published in "Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (six volumes) compiled by Kokugakuin, its revised edition "Zotei Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Revised Edition of the Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (twelve volumes, published by Yoshikawa Kobunkan), "Kohon Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Conflated Edition of the Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (on his thoughts, two volumes) and "Kamo no Mabuchi Zenshu" (The Complete Works of Kamo no Mabuchi) (twenty-eight volumes, published by Zokugun Shorui Ju Kanseikai) edited by Senichi HISAMATSU.

sen.j: 真淵は教育者としても長じ、門下生には本居宣長・荒木田久老（あらきだ・ひさおゆ）・加藤千蔭・村田春海・楫取魚彦（かとり・なひこ）・塙保己一（はなわ・ほきいち）・内山真龍・栗田土満（ひじまろ）・森繁子などがおり、県居学派と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Mabuchi was also a good teacher and his disciples include Norinaga MOTOORI, Hisaoyu ARAKIDA, Chikage KATO, Harumi MURATA, Nahiko KATORI, Hokiichi HANAWA, Matatsu UCHIYAMA, Hijimaro KURITA and Shigekiko MORI; their school was called Agatai.

Mabuchi was also a good teacher and his disciples include Norinaga MOTOORI, Hisaoyu ARAKIDA, Chikage KATO, Harumi MURATA, Nahiko KATORI, Hokiichi HANAWA, Matatsu UCHIYAMA, Hijimaro KURITA and Shigekiko MORI; their school was called Agatai.

Mabuchi was also a good teacher and his disciples include Norinaga MOTOORI, Hisaoyu ARAKIDA, Chikage KATO, Harumi MURATA, Nahiko KATORI, Hokiichi HANAWA, Matatsu UCHIYAMA, Hijimaro KURITA and Shigekiko MORI; their school was called Agatai.

sen.j: 高名な弟子として以下の7人の名が知られている。
sen.e: The following seven people are known as his prominent disciples.
The following seven people are known as his prominent disciples.
The following seven people are known as his prominent disciples.

sen.j: その内特に優れた女性3人を県門の三才女（けんもんのさんさいじょ）と称し、特に優れた男性4人を県門の四天王（けんもんのしてんのう）と称した。
sen.e: Among them, the three most talented women were called Kenmon no Sansaijo (the three talented women of the Agatai school) and the four most talented men were called Kenmon no Shitenno (the four talented men of the Agatai school).

Among them, the three most talented women were called Kenmon no Sansaijo (the three talented women of the Agatai school) and the four most talented men were called Kenmon no Shitenno (the four talented men of the Agatai school).

sen.j: また、県門の四天王に8人を加え、県門十二大家（けんもんじゅうにたいか）と称される場合もある。
sen.e: Eight disciples are sometimes added to Kenmon no Shitenno and collectively referred to as Kenmon Junitaika.
